name: NOT A HERO
description: Professional assassin turned amateur campaign manager Steve is charged with cleaning up the city by an anthropomorphic rabbit and mayoral candidate from the future named BunnyLord.
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows 7 or later Processor: Intel from 2GHz or equivilent AMD family Memory: 2 GB RAM Graphics: 2GB Video Memory DirectX: Version 9.0 Storage: 500 MB available space Additional Notes: Xbox 360/Xbox One/Dualshock 4 controller recommended.

reviews.review_text: The entire premise of the game is essentially shoot baddies stylishly and see how many windows it takes to shatter your skull.  P.S: Lots of puns  P.P.S: I mean seriously they never end

I started off loving this game, I really did. Want to know why I gave it a thumbs down? The boredom. Each level seems to be a copy and paste scene with copy and pasted characters from previous levels. The limited controls and bizarre keybinds puzzled me, because through options you couldn't change the arrow keys to i don't know... the WASD keys AND you couldn't change the shoot, roll, and special weapon keys either. You'll find yourself about 30 minutes into the game wondering why you bought the game when you realize that there is nothing unique in the upcoming levels and that the Bunny's little speeches before levels don't benefit you whatsoever.   Overall, a nice concept and story line but bad execution made me very down on this game. Worth $12? Maybe. Not a first choice for $12 games though
Silently released without adds or something. Secret gem. A must play, so much fun. Run&Gun
Actual British politics would be interesting if BunnyLord was involved.
It's alright, just repetitive.

NOT A HERO is a tongue in cheek comedic high violence platformer starring you as one of the many assistants to an enigmatic character known as Bunnylord. Your purpose in the game is to complete various missions for BL in the hopes of helping him to win an election.   The graphics are pretty retro, but not offensively so. The music is catchy and the characters’ banter entertaining. As far as gameplay goes, the concepts are fairly simple (shoot, enter cover, reload, dash, tackle, execute) and can be picked up fairly quickly after the first tutorial mission. Depending on the character you choose, your style of run and gun will differ and some people will be easier to play on certain levels than others.  I kind of liked the limited mobility factor in that you cannot jump in this game and must instead make your way up various nearby buildings and dive through windows to progress in some areas. The slide tackle mechanic is also a nice addition and combined with execution, if timed right, it can make for a downright frantic yet rewarding experience. Some enemies in the game are immune to the aforementioned combo and must be dealt with in other ways.  Overall I think this is a nice game that yields around 7-10 hours depending on whether or not you want to get the full ending or just clear it. Some of the levels have some really hard challenges like “don’t get punched” or some sort of time-based objective, which can be kind of a drag if you manage to finally pull it off and then die or get punched right near the end of a level (this happened to me a lot). That being said, this game regularly goes on sale for less than $5 and is a total steal at that price. Worth it just for the voice acting and goofy plot.
Three words: Money. Well. Spent.

Things I find cool in this game: Bunnylord Cat Bombs Helicopters That you can actually do all things from the trailer Grannies Cut Scenes Did I mentioned helicopters?  10/10 Would vote Bunnylord again

Would a purple homicidal anthropomorphic rabbit from the future be a better ruler than the real ones we have today? Sadly, the answer is: quite possibly. And that’s exactly the premise of Not a Hero from London-based developer Roll7 that already made a name for itself with the acclaimed side-scrolling skateboarding game OlliOlli. The idea presented by BunnyLord is that, for some reason, the world will end unless he gets elected mayor. The polls aren’t in BunnyLord’s favor and apparently the best way to turn voter opinion around is to assemble a crew of misfits who will brutally and mercilessly poke crime in its ugly face. Well, we’ve certainly seen worse election campaigns.  The story is about as preposterous as it sounds. BunnyLord is obsessed with milkshakes, turtles, pandas and murder (oh, and cheese) and will send the player to perform a wide range of tasks through the territory of three stereotypical gangs. However, all of these tasks basically boil down to killing everyone in your path. It’s a good thing then that killing in this game is really well done. Not a Hero is a 2D side-scrolling cover-based shooter on two planes with the second plane acting as cover. It’s an instantly intuitive system as both you and your enemies are slightly shaded upon entering cover. There’s no jumping in the game, but sliding serves as a substitute mechanic and it is pulled off brilliantly. Basically, you can slide to move faster and also to tackle enemies which enables you to execute them point blank. However, there are enemies that cannot be tackled and they have to be avoided and shot from a distance.  The first character you have at your disposal is BunnyLord’s best friend Steve, but as you go through missions and increase BunnyLord’s standing in the polls, more characters will join your cause. Every character has a distinct amusing personality and it is obvious that this is a very British game. I never got tired of hearing Steve shout “fookin’ ‘ell” as he encountered droves of enemies. Then there’s Cletus (“Dressed like a hillbilly, but actually from Scotland”), Samantha from Wales (“Valley girls last longer!”), Jesus from Spain who has formidable hip-thrusting skills and my favorite, Mike from Northern England with a constant eye twitch most likely indicating a murderous sociopath. There are nine characters in total to unlock and more importantly than their personality, each of them has different skills, weapons and abilities which completely changes the way you go through a level. For example, Steve’s specialty is tackling, Mike performs silent executions, Stanley has high rate of fire good for crowd control whereas Jesus is a really fast runner and performs executions while moving.  The map design is good, but rather straightforward. Each level offers some additional objectives that occasionally take you away from the main route, but most of the time there’s just one way to go through a level. Apart from a helicopter encounter, there aren’t any setpieces to mix things up a bit and offer a bit of diversity. Even during the three boss fights, you’re more of a bystander taking care of other enemies while BunnyLord takes care of the boss. The game does throw you in the fire a bit with enemies popping up unexpectedly most notably when the SWAT teams enter the building and start chasing you down. Enemies also drop various power ups for your weapon and secondary weapons such as grenades or turrets are also scattered through each level.  The game uses pixel art for its graphics and while it’s pleasant, the art style isn’t particularly strong. The same can be said for the soundtrack which uses retro 8-bit music. The goal was obviously going for a retro feel in a more modern package, but neither component really stands out. The controls and the mechanics are tight and responsive. The game runs well for the most part, although I did experience some slowdown in certain places. It’s not anything major, but it is noticeable due to the nature of the game which requires pinpoint precision and speed. There’s a bit of trial and error as the game demands you to memorize the level layout and enemies and then perform really well in order to get to the end because you have to start over from the beginning each time you die. This does get just a bit frustrating, however, the mechanics are so well implemented that you’ll definitely want to jump back in and finish the level. It has that addictive element to it and once you master it, the sense of accomplishment is great indeed.  The game’s biggest drawback is its short length and lack of longevity. Once you finish up the 21 levels in the game all of which are very short, there’s little incentive to go on. You can go through levels with different characters to get better results, but it’s not that compelling. It’s a shame that the game doesn’t support Steam achievements as those would possibly facilitate more gameplay experimentation and provide more incentive to re-visit a level, if wisely implemented. I also have one gripe regarding the story. The premise is great, but the game doesn’t really take it anywhere. Sure, there are a lot of jokes here, but a more engaging political satire, which is actually hinted at in the trailers and the advertising but which is not in the actual game, would go a long way to make this game not only more current and relevant, but also more humorous. Based on the pre-release campaign, I expected something like a gaming equivalent of a cross between the senseless slapstick violence of Bottom and the edgy political satire of The New Statesman. Which would have been brilliant. As it is, though, Not a Hero is only half way there in that regard.  Not a Hero is a very enjoyable game thanks to its tight mechanics, exhilarating gameplay and humorous story. There’s definitely room for improvement and seeing as how the ending leaves the door wide open for a sequel, it will be very interesting to see what Roll7 does next as the foundation laid here is strong indeed.  7 OUT OF 10 (VERY GOOD)
All around masterpiece and remember: Bomb=No drugs. Violence today, for a better tomorrow.
A challenging but fair shooter with it's own unique style. The kind of game that makes you rage and laugh but so good you want to beat it.

Play as your favorite characters: Nathan Drake, Random Redneck guy, Female James Bond, A Rapey Latino, A literal serial killer..?, Cory in the House, James Bond, Discount Thor, and Lilo and Stitch rated R.
The Bunnylord deserves my vote.
Fun, hilarious but a little repetitive after a while. Still, an overall good game.

It's a lot of fun to play and the story is funny as hell. Typically it's a 2D shoot and cover type game and you will die a lot due to how hard it gets at times but it feels good when you manage to complete a level.  If you enjoy a challenge, give this a shot.  Also vote bunnylord.
It's fun, it's funny, it's got Bunnylord. What more could you want?

Meh it's ok. I like it alright but it's right on the edge. I probably wouldn't recommend it to my friends. It has it's problems and the controls aren't as tight as I'd like. Also the presentation is a little weak. The text is so slow I just wanted to skip the cut scenes.

First off, let me give credit to where credits due. The game is cute, its adorable in a dark slapstick, nonsense kind of way, with colorful characters and a very fun story. The gameplay? Frustrating... tedious. It reminds me of Hotline Miami, but instead of having floors and checkpoints, your expected to do the whole level with one life. It makes the game fun... until you die the first time, then you repeat what you did, die again often from frustration and carelessness, then repeat what you did again, over and over again, until you finally complete the mission with all of the challenges thrown in. Its nerve wracking, its frustrating, I never have fun playing this game. The first few levels were a blast, because they werent to difficult and I was allowed to complete them in my own way, having fun with the levels. Towards the end you will be memorizing every single enemy encounter, every single time you shoot you will count your shots to reload so you dont make a turn only to find you have no bullets in your gun and instantly die from a katana.   In short, the game is a grind, a completionist grind where you have to behave in a scripted, overly cautious manor to complete any of the end game levels, thus making all the color and humor pointless.

A funny 2D shooter that is amazingly difficult but even more rewarding, all the silly characters and fun powerups fused into one makes this game one of a kind, there's nothing really bad to say about it!
Old school 80s difficulty, punishing yet rewarding. Great 8-Bit soundtrack and voice acting  Voted Bunnylord!

This game is awesome  Pros: +Fun and really addictive +Easy to play +Funny Dialogue +Interesting characters, each with their own different playstyles +Fast paced +Once you die, you start over the level, makes you think more strategically  Cons: -Somewhat short -If you dont have a controller you may have a VERY bad time; one simple mistake between reolads can lead to you being punched in the face and killed, especially in the later stages of the game -Most of the characters are kinda useless if youre trying to get global megalord rating or just passing a level for that matter (personally i found that shotguns were the answer to almost all problems.......... and a katana) -Once you die, you start over (can be a con for some people i guess)  VOTE BUNNYLORD!!!!!!
false difficulty and terrible reload system. there's fast gameplay and then theres obnoxious gameplay
Good pixel art   Boring dialogs   Dull gameplay.  If you want to play something similar, try Broforce, Hotline Miami, Super Time Force Ultra or Super crate box.

After watching some gameply, you ought to be familiar with how the game mechanics are. It's fun, there are numerous slightly-different characters and a lot of levels to go through. Unfortunately, even in the hours I have put in it (only 3.6 hours so far) it has become extremely repetitive and the jokes which were funny in the first hour are already stale.   It's alright. I don't recommend purchasing it unless $2.50 and you acknowledge that you are getting a story-less, repetitive 2D shooter with minor puzzle elements.  The trailer of the game made me think it'd be crazier with more activities. I should have watched gameplay. Even then, I still would have purchased it at the low cost I did. At full price, the humor/charm would not be enough to carry it for very long.

Not my type of game,bored me, couldn't finish past level 8. Progression based solely on   optional   challenges. Advertised as hotline miami mixed with broforce, and it couldnt be more off of that. Nothing about these games resembles NOT A HERO. Humor is completely 'LOL XD RANDOM' type humor    which is absolutely not humor   .

I would compare this game to Hotline Miami like so many other people do, but it's far-off from it.  Not a Hero is a game where you are a amateur campaign manager/assassin tasked with cleaning up crime in the city. Your boss is an anthro rabbit from the future, and he gives you some ridiculous tasks sometimes. In one level you're murdering drug dealers and in the next you're rescuing giant rat heads. Whatever the case, you need to take down crime bosses in the end, specifically a Russian mob boss, a backstreet gang leader, and a triad yakuza boss.  The game is very fast-paced, as I was able to complete the first 2 chapters in only 3 hours. It has the interesting mechanics of ducking for cover and sliding under your enemies to stun them. There are 8 unique characters, each having their own weapon or ability. Cletus wields a shotgun, Ronald uses melee only, ect. One of the more interesting parts of this game is the powerups and usable weapons. With them, you can shoot lasers, explosive rounds, or pretty much anything out of your gun, as well as throw molotovs, ricochet grenades or a cat that explodes near an enemy. There's even secret levels and challenges as you go along, but I could never unlock the secret levels or complete all 3 challenges.  Overall, the game has a nice feel to it, although it would help if the soundtrack was a bit better in some cases. I like the pixel graphics and sidescrolling design of it, and it's always fun to play a political game where you can beat someone's face in with a hammer.  I rate this an 8.5/10. I would reccommend this to my friends.

Just before I begin I would like to thank my good friend for gifting this game to me. :)  Okay this one I have a bit of mixed views on. NOT A HERO is a comedic shooter where you help an anthropomorphic bunny... From the future *wink* named Bunnylord win an election by fighting crime with a bullet to the head. It's essentially a cover based 2.5D shooter. Graphics are pixelated and look nice, you can choose from a list of Bunnylord's supporters to fight in these levels and each have their own abilities and unique attributes. The humor is my style of awkward weird which I like and the music is just kick ♥♥♥. Every level has a set of optional tasks which can alter the game's ending which I am personally not a fan of but I can see the appeal of.  Now the problem I have with this game which you'll surely notice when playing around the second half of the game is that it's cheap. It is really cheap at times with one hit death enemies and a lot of trial and error. The last few levels can seriously go F*CK themselves because they are really unforgiving. The characters you can play as seem unbalanced such as with Mike being personally the most useful out of all of them. The time it took for me to play this would have been halved if the level design for some of the levels weren't so unbalanced and unfair. I would not suggest playing this game if you have a really short temper.  Still this game is quirky and you can have a lot of fun with it when you're in the right mood. I'll give this game a 7.5/10. The humor alone is worth a look at if you're into awkward weirdness. That and the combat can be really fun when the level design isn't so cheap.
It was fun to play the game that inspired Trump's campaign.
It's like a european version of broforce! Except funnier! Love it! I wish it was longer though. Please make a sequal.

Cover-based shooters barely count as entertaining in 3D, and it falls flat on its face in this 2D delve into the genre. The action is overly simplistic. The 'humor' is just really really bad. Maybe it's British humor (sorry for the oxymoron), but I didn't find anything about the game amusing. The chatter during gameplay was irritating as well. I don't think it counts as a bad game, but it's certainly not for me. There are countless other better 2D shooters that I don't feel compeled to play this one anymore.

A game like this hinges on two things: gameplay and writing (in this case humor). The gameplay is mediocre, but enoyable enough. The writing is where it falls absolutely flat. Let me put it this way: If you are twelve years old and find 'lol random spork le maymay' humor funny, then this will be your jam. If you are a grown-♥♥♥ person, skip it. Nearly all of the humor in the game is essentially, 'Haha, I'm saying a random word. Banana!'   It's criminally unfunny. A random person off the street could write better comedy. I would honestly be surprised if their writer was over the age of 15. Kudos, I guess, for letting a child express themselves. The kid really needed some guidance though.   tl;dr If you want an action game with decent writing, you're not going to find it here. The gameplay is just ok; definitely not enough to prop up the sophomoric 'lol spork! penguin!' children's humor.  I actually ended up returning it since the 'humor,' a bulk of the game's appeal, fell so utterly flat.  Final verdict:  BUY: If you're in middle school or below.  DO NOT BUY: If you're old enough to legally hold a job.

Devolver Digital does it again, the game look great and upon wathcing the trailers I felt excited for some high octane dynamic action. The controls are arrows left and right to move, x to slide to cover, c to shoot and space bar to reload. That's it the whole game is move to cover, shoot and reload. certain characters change that up a bit but it's never truly hard. there is some difficulty if you want to get the achievements and maybe later levels would be harder but I don't care to go that far. The difficulty is all just inunderstanding that amachine gun guy will kill you 100% if you go up these stairs at the wrong time in his walking pattern. It's another concept heavy, gameplay light, 16 bit flop for me.    3/10
Obnoxious forced humour that wasn't funny more than a decade ago. Could be an ok time-waster if you can overcome the cringe.

The humor gets old very quickly, the controls are strange and you cannot remap them. I'd rather have seen an experience where I aim with the mouse. Ultimately, just a distraction on your way to greater games. Skip it.

What I liked:      Music is from chiptune artists ( some I already owned)     Character all have different weapons and abilities and uses   What You Need to Know:      Bunnylord's 'Voice' will get annoying ( skipped alot of cutscenes )     Combat has this cover mechanic that isn't as responsive for how fast the gameplay is( neat concept though)     Humor is mostly a random mish mash of words and hardly made me laugh ( had a couple good ones though)     Has desktop soundpack for Windows :0 ( MegaLord Edition)    My Score:
EPIC ♥♥♥♥ WOMBATS PLAY IT TO GET THE REFRENCE

With a preview article appearing in free London rag 'The Metro', it seemed that NOT A HERO was destined for great things in May 2015. However, due to a release delay & several unfortunate control related hiccups at launch it seemingly fizzled away without the usual hype you seem to see from the YouTubers let's playing the current indie darling.  This title is a 2.5D (or Iso-slant as they call it) fast paced, pixel art cover shooter. Think Gunpoint mixed with the frantic action of Hotline Miami. You're tasked with helping an anthropomorphic alien known as BUNNYLORD to become mayor. His main strategy which he'll brief you with in hilariously randomized pre-level sequences is to mostly 'kill people very dead awesomely' and also drink milkshakes.  Roll7 are an English studio and it tells through this game with almost all the main characters given regional UK dialects. While it doesn't offer much of anything in the way of story or character development, it's a nice touch to distinguish different skill types on your controllable protagonist.  While getting from one end of a level to the end isn't particularly difficult, each stage will come with several additional challenges. Most are time or kill streak related & nearing the end of the game, these will require almost pin-point reflexes and stratagem to make it through.  While the game itself is a lot of fun, humorous & challenging, the major flaws arrive in that only 1 of the 8 or so unlockable characters (Mike) is actually a viable option to complete the game & all its challenges. While it's still amusing to dabble with the others, more balancing should have been carried out to provide more possiblities in playing the game & using all the characters in a different fashion.  Keeping in mind the scope & budget of the game, it would have also been nice to see a bit more story originating from Bunnylord's FUN CLUB members.  While perhaps not in the upper echelon of the current golden age of indie steam titles, it's still rather good. Hopefully this won't be the last we see of Bunnylord from Roll7. While it's £10 full price might be a hard sell to those who weren't already sold on the trailer (which is still dare I say one of the best on the service), it'd almost be impossible to pick this up during a sale or bundle & not have a good time.

- no steam achievement - rely on skill and reaction which is super good but cannot change game key or keybindings  + funny humor in game and the steam discussion + good characters + neat cover mechanics + quick levels + hardcore game with some hardcore challenges + stats that records win/fail ratio and life expectancy per stage to remind you how suck you are + cats and turtles and robots + nice art + admirable music + oh and some guns and shootings and runnings and executions and explosions and glass breaking hollywood style  must buy on sale!
The voices make the game. Basically. It gets hard but it stays fun all the way through
A veritable bloodbath of awesome, although slightly repetitive, this game is a must try for anyone who enjoys side scrollers and massive amounts of murder.

Apparently it had a lot of issues before the patch (sep 30) but because I waited for Linux/achievements I never saw any issues.  This is a really slick and simple game. It's like a double dragon / metal slug / hotline Miami.  I'm already half way through the levels in an hour but there are 3 secondary objectives each level that really help to pad them out.  I think some people won't like repeating levels to finish the game but adding different characters helps with that as well.

Not a Hero is the first of its kind; a 2d cover shooter. While I initially expected a Gears of War or Mass Effect 3-esque playstyle, this is actually a more realized, albeit slower less twitch version of Hotline Miami. The dialogue and voice overs, however, are what make this game a blast to play. The different playstyles of each character combined with the three mission objectives to get a higher approval rating are what give this game replayability.   Every mission should end at a diner with an acceptable breakfast and a milkshake. 9.5/10
Hilarious pixelated rage game? What's not to love!
I like this. It's funny, clever, and very nicely presented.  However.  It is difficult and the controls are periodically annoying.
THIS GAME IS A BLAST!, frantic, fast-paced, incredibly fun.
Highly entertaining!

So, I just finished the game with most of the optional stuff and all the characters unlocked, so I think I have agood basis to give my opinion on this game.  Pro: + short levels make for good short sessions. Also doesn't make one feel too bad if you die and have to redo the whole level. + quick paced + variety of characters you can unlock, all with different playstyles (though that doesn't become that apparent for the first 4 imo, or maybe it's just understanding the game mechanics better that makes you get why and how these character play rather differently) + replayability for the optional missions (which are quite hard sometimes) + overall good level and enemy design + can be quite difficult at some points, especially if you go for all the optional stuff   Cons: - Level design in terms of presentation. There are 3 worlds with the same basic design, the first two are rather a bit boring and not so nice to look at. Not much detail, mostly in the same color (or shades of the same color) - Controls can be really annoying sometimes. The slide and cover button are the same, meaning that you'll always slide into cover, which works really nice most of the time, but it will also leave you not being able to take cover if the cover is too close to your position, which usually leads to sliding into the enemies or their firerange. Really annoying. Also The shoot and execute(when enemies lie on the ground) button is the same, so you can end up wanting to shoot that guy running at you, but you will instead execute the guy on the ground, which (since you can't cancel it and takes quite a few seconds) will usually get you killed. - Visibility issues sometimes. Powerups are always in the front, so enemies can sometimes 'hide' behind them. Same problem if there's too much carnage (though that rarely happens). All in all this is not a big problem and rarely ever happens, but of course IF it happens it sucks hard to be shot at or killed by an enemy you didn't even soo, even though he was right in front of you.  Overall the game was and is a lot of fun and I'm happy I bought it, but be prepared for some frustration every now and again, as a result of control issues.
Comedic, frantic, and one hell of a chalenge. Lovers of hotline and gunpoint will feel right at home.
I'm reporting this game... because it's ♥♥♥♥ing amazeballs!!!
Perfect for speedrunners, Nice challenges, and a wide variety of characters with very... unique personalities

A few minor issues, but Not a Hero has a lot of potential. The writing is hilarious and the animation is fantastic. A solid hi-octane 2D shooter.  Read my full  Not a Hero review  [www.therockstargamers.com]

Over-the-top fun and gratuitous shooting and sliding. Weird, cynical, and oddly cute humor. I'll never beat the bonus challenges with my reflexes, but I can take my time, finish the levels, and laugh at it all.

So... yeah.  NOT A HERO is not a strategy, not a horror, not a RPG, it is a shooter. Basically about the purple bunny from the future being elected as mayor by kicking the crime in the balls with your help. Lots of fun. Let's keep it short from here.  The graphics are nice, somewhat reminding us that the games don't have to look grey. Or dusked blue, or orange, it is supposed to look like a milkshake!  The gameplay is fast, interesting and fun.  The music is the best music you could ever find in a game like this. THE BEST  But beware. Trailer says 'don't afraid of getting shot'. You will be shot and chopped to pieces a lot. Because of it you will feel bad about the absolute absence of checkpoints at the levels. When I finished the game, which is short, I felt very tired of it. It doesn't need as much precision as Hotline Miami, but... hell, Hotline Miami seemed easier somehow.  Basically, if you liked the trailer, you will probably like the game.
Holy ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. i just bought this game and holy ♥♥♥♥ is it glorius. buy this if you want a great time for hours on end.    and a pink spandex-wearing, dry-humping jesus.  yup.

While I was supposed to be shooting drug dealers in Bredrin Park, I was 'farting around' in a magical door and then went to Aunt Ruby's for a milkshake.  The game feels repetitive at times and is not worth $13.99. BUT, If it goes on sale, you should give NOT A HERO a shot for action, violence and laughs.  8/10

NOT A HERO is a pretty cool game! Graphically well made, musically awesome, the gameplay is simple but effective, some levels are really challenging but not unbeatable! A cool game! Count 10-12h for 100% completion.
This is candidate hillarys story but with a rabbit instead

While it looks like a simple game where you simply start running and shooting without giving it much of a thought, it is actually quite comparable to Hotline Miami in terms of depth, as you need to plan your way ahead.
A truly challenging and fun 2D shooter

Crazy game, completely bonkers, but from the hilarious dialogue to the surprisingly clear and basic graphics, this is just a smart game. Totally over the top violence and gore, witty scripting and for a good price. Worth a spot in anyone's collection. (Warning: addictive!)
Its greate fun and well made. just play it.

This game in one sentence would be this.  Badass flying around with a shotgun murdering people for a middle aged bunny who is running for mayor to ruler of the galaxy depending on how well you can execute missions and your enemies with cat bombs, grenades, and if capable, giant hammers.  My real review would be. This game has great controls and is very fast like hotline miami. It's great if you just want to kill time and ninjas. It's worth every cent that you pay and will be one of your favorite games. My only issue is that it can get old kind of quick but that's just because i've spent 4 hours one time getting a perfect score on one level just to loose all the data because that's just lovely.

This game is hard and unforgiving, but is worth it for a great set of jokes, one after the other. There will be times were you will smash your keyboard trying to get all of the achievements in a level, but you will find it worth the effort when you go into the cafe with Bunnylord and laugh at the witty dialogue.
Gets very repetative   7/10 IGN
the best pixel game ever
super fun fast-paced 2d game. the cutscenes are hilarious and easy to skip when you're on replay #50. great game i'd recommend it if it were $20
The sidescroller mix of Hotline Miami and Killer7 you never knew you needed.

Great game on all fronts. - Technically robust. - Tight pacing. - Charming characters. - Great humor. - Fast and satisfying gameplay. - Challenging but fair. - Hilarious (if inconsequential) use of random elements in dialog and level objectives. - Great sound design and soundtrack.  The only gripe that I remember having were the scripted events in the last level, which made it furstrating to replay due to the unskippable waits they introduced in an otherwise extremely fast-paced game.  Wholeheartedly recommended.
10/10 would blow up Ganja again

NOT A HERO is fast-paced, at times quite brutally difficult, insanely satisfying to play and just tremendous fun. The cutscenes, which slightly vary each time, adding some extra fun to replaying levels for that last challenge you missed. Only played the first 8 missions so far, completed the challenges on about half of them. 13€ is a bit steep, but if you are a fan of 2D-shooters, fast-paced action gameplay with tactical and stealth elements and replaying the same ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ level 30 times in a row, pick up a copy! When on sale, it's definitely worth it!

If I had to condense why I love and hate this game down I would write it as sound effects that consist of screaming in fruastration, crying, then dancing constantly looping every minute. The game is really fun and challenging to those who want to complete the game. There are two problems I have with the game. 1. The game is kind of buggy. There have been times where I fight floating ghost samuri's or the I am about to beat the game 100% and woops the game crashed again! 2. the other problem I have is the final boss at stage 21 is a pain in the @$$ to deal with when your trying to complete the game and where I problem spent hours of my life trying to beat. Other then that I honestly would recomend this and its DLC .

5/10  i was so bored, after only 4'ish levels i simply quit, may take it up another time but for now there are better games to be played, it's actually a luxury problem, as a standard platformer, the game ain't that bad. but the fact is, games like Gunpoint, Mark of the ninja and BroForce does exist. Not a hero misses well balanced mechanics like those games, for an example in-level objectives and puzzle elements like in gunpoint, or the way you can create your own paths in BroForce by shooting your way through.  So for now, it's a thumbs down, despite the game actually look great, nice sound and funny story line, which may be the only reason i may revisit it sometime in the future.
In this game, you go door to door, canvassing and murdering.
Frantic twitchy shooty bang bang with the occasional carrot stabbing! The writing is also pretty fantastic, full of absurdist humour and magnificently british insults.

A cover-based slide'n'gun. I like the concept but it does kind of feel like all you have to do is mash the shoot button very fast most of the time. The game's a lot of shooting, and spacing yourself away from enemies to give yourself time to reload or regain health. Most of the difficulty comes from the time trial challenges, and they're mostly frustrating because some enemy position are random which will screw up a run, but you might still have fun ignoring the challenges, but this game is probably insanely short if you do. Took me 8 hours to 100% it, and that's a boatload of retries. There are about 8-ish characters with different weapon and skills, enough to make you have to play the levels very differently.

I picked it up for around 5 bucks. The $$$/hour is good in this one. In a bit over 7 hours you can get all the achievements.   Not a hard game if you are used to difficult-levels such as Hotline Miami or similar but just as enjoyable. Sometimes frustrating but it feels like most of the time it is your own fault, not the games if something does not work out as planned.  9 Characters with different quirks and abilties and a lot of charme. Too bad in the game itself it felt like some characters are more useful in more situations than others. For example, I stuck with Steve until I unlocked Mike and then rolled with him the majority of the game. After I unlocked Ronald I played with him as well every now and then but Kimmy was pretty much useless as I felt.  Nice crude humor and a lot of love was put into some details. I like it.  If you are an Achievement Completionist, thats your pick-up.

I found this far easier and more digestible than Hot Line Miami, probably due to the fact that you have regenerating health and sidescrolling 2D view which make shooting and moving around far easier for me. I love the weird humour, the clichéd yet hiliarous voice acting and the viceral but minimalistic visual effects.  After 12 hours I got all achievements, finished the Campaign and I'm very pleased that Bunnyload was elected as Global Megalord.  Needless to say, Bunnylord had my vote on election day!  Will vote him again 10/10
This aint Hotlime miami. but sure is a difficult game, (nice game)
♥♥♥♥ing funny howeverthe gameplay is pretty fiddly, play it for the comedy the gameplay wasnt for me to be honest.
Great trailer + great game, even if it's a bit short. If it's on sale, buy it. #noregrets

I'm torn on this one. First, I'd like to stress how much personality this game has. You won't forget Bunnylord and the overall style of this game. It does remind us of Hotline Miami with its violence and color scheme, but it has its own twist of humor. Lot's of funnny voice acting and characters to enjoy. Maybe kinda cheesy for some, but it will make you chuckle at some points.  But humor and style ain't enough: it's the challenging gameplay that should take the cake in these kind of violent games. It's face-paced, intense and hectic. You don't need to master to game to play throught he campaign, but eventually you want to get all the objectives crossed off the list. This gets good once you get the appropiate characters you unlock. But these objectives require you to do stuff that some challenges the mechanics more than they do you...  For instance, the objective 'don't get punched' sounds way easier than it is, considering you also need to complete the objective 'reach the reported in x amount of seconds'. After finishing the game, I still don't get WHY I can't tackle an enemy but get punched instead. Is it because he is shooting? Or because he is reloading? In either case, I had a 50% chance of succefully tackling him. Another problem was taking cover (which you do with the same button as with tackling). Sometimes my character wouldn't take cover at the column right in front of him, but instead slight right into the fist of an enemy.   This was headache inducing especially in the last level.  I did get bored with it at times and went back to it at other times, when I DID enjoy its repetitive nature. It was then, that I enjoyed the unlocked characters and its straight forward gameplay.  Lastly, I there are technical problems, some of which has been resolved since its release. Some still do persist, like the inactive cloud saves (so back-up before you uninstall!) and the occasional crash to desktop when restarting the level for the 10th time.  Try out the game. Get a refund if it doesn't gell with you, which I would totally understand. Personally, I was suprised that this game was made by only one guy, which I think is atleast worth mentioning.
